headline: This free online course provides a framework in which to explore the intersections of literature, culture and media.
description: This free online course covers the impact of literature, culture and media on public trends, beliefs and debates. We guide you through the complex ways that one influences the other and the theories that explain these links. We look at social movements like feminism through the lens of the interwoven disciplines of cultural, political and media studies to appreciate the influence of changing information technology on our public narratives.

courseDescription:
This free online course investigates the socio-political impact of the evolution of literature, culture and media and the technology that connects them. From Johann Gutenburg’s fifteenth century printing press to today’s e-books, mass media have evolved from word-of-mouth to online comments sections and virtual reality. Culture has absorbed these changes and rapidly adjusted to suit its social climate and rejects tradition to embrace postmodernism.

This course unpacks the complex ways in which society and culture form new perspectives and ideologies. We begin with theories that examine various philosophical and cultural topics. This enables you to deconstruct literature in a critical way and appreciate why the idea of a ‘text’ is often redefined. We follow various theoretical discussions of contemporary culture, literature and the power dynamics that affect their reception.

We study a number of shifting social, political and artistic perceptions that drive postmodernism in the twenty-first century. This course helps you to understand the profound influence of these three subjects on each other over the centuries. We consider the role of technological advancement on mass media and the movement of narratives and ideas to offer you a richer understanding of the complex relationship between literature, culture and media. This course suits anyone working in the fields of media and communication or who simply wants to understand how our lives are affected by the stories we tell to make sense of the world and ourselves.

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will get an insight into the aims and objectives of this course. It defines literature and culture, highlighting the changing perceptions. It explains the influence of cultural, social and philosophical forces on media forms and literature. This module introduces the linkages between literature, culture, media and technology.

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module describes the linkages and developments between literature and cultural studies. It discusses the contributions and philosophies of some major theorists such as – Raymond Williams, a Welsh Marxist theorist and Stuart Hall, a Jamaican born, British Marxist sociologist. It also highlights and describes the differences between the concepts of high culture, popular culture, subculture and counterculture.

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module introduces and explains some theories of modernism and postmodernism and provides the differences. It also describes the peripheral aspects of the theoretical groundings including metanarratives, knowledge and power and post-structuralism and deconstruction by in-depth analysis of the works of Lyotard, Foucault, Saussure and Derrida.
topics: Postmodernism – Development and Impact: Learning Outcomes
Lyotard's The Postmodern Condition: A Report on Knowledge
Foucault's Notion of Knowledge and Power
Postmodernism – Development and Impact: Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: Feminism and gender are two words which are often discussed and are a part of our daily vocabulary. This module focuses on discussions related to feminism and gender issues. It traces the origins of feminism, describes key theories and development of feminist arguments. It will cover the beginnings of gender, masculinity and queer studies.
topics: Feminism and Gender Studies: Learning Outcomes
Queer Studies and Representation of Gender in Media
Feminism and Gender Studies: Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: Postmodernist thoughts led to the development of feminism and gender studies which gradually intersected with race. This module focuses on intersectionality. It explores how the theoretical approaches for gender, race and ethnicity have developed in the late 20th century, taking a specific shape and leading to a particular idea for our worldview.
topics: Postcolonial Reading of Achebe and Amitav Ghosh

modules.name: Module
modules.description: The terms culture and ideology have multiple meanings and interpretations. So, it is difficult to identify their point of convergence. Both these terms embrace the non-material and subjective aspect of human existence. This module focuses on culture and explains the abstract and intricate theories of ideology, identity and culture industry.
topics: Culture – Ideology, Identity and Linkages: Learning Outcomes
Culture Industry, Mass Deception and Walter Benjamin
Interconnection between Literature, Culture and Identity: Woolf and Deshpande I
Interconnection between Literature, Culture and Identity: Woolf and Deshpande II
Culture – Ideology, Identity and Linkages: Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This is an assessment on the previous six modules on this course. You will need 80% to pass.
topics: First Assessment: Literature, Culture and Media

modules.name: Module
modules.description: We can trace the beginnings of media to the human temperament of communicating with each other in order to pass on our messages to feel connected and be a part of society. This module focuses on media and explains the interconnections between culture, media and literature. It describes how they are being continuously shaped by each other.
topics: The Evolution of Media: Print Forms

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In the 20th century, Marshall McLuhan was a profound voice in the context of media theories within which he analysed the development of human history. This module introduces you to McLuhan's works and the impact of new electric media. It also discusses the postmodern media and highlights the work of Baudrillard and the influence of social media.
topics: Media in the 20th Century: Learning Outcomes
Postmodern Media and Formation of Public Opinion
Media in the 20th Century: Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: People have always tried to link words with certain images in their desire to express emotions and sensibilities. This module takes you on a journey from cave drawings to the projection of moving images, to highlight the interdependency of culture and media. It explores the development of art of cinema and explains some technical terms associated with films. The module concludes with a critical analysis of a film– 12 years a Slave, to understand how films and literary text enrich each other.
topics: Word and the Image: Drama, Photography, Birth of the Cinema
Language of Films: Mise-en-scene, Types of Shots, Camera Angles and Movements, Montage
Reading of 12 Years a Slave: Film and Text

modules.name: Module
modules.description: The journey of media began with handwritten novels, printed newspapers and books and progressed through the development of radio, television, internet and now we are living in a world of digital media and social media. This module traces the development of media, beginning with radio and television, in the context of its influence on culture and literature. It looks at the views and theories of technologys impact on literary genres and concludes with a discussion on media in the 21st century.
topics: Impact of Technology on Literary Genres: Novel

modules.name: Module
modules.description: Many literary scholars believe that the meaning of literature should be comprehended within the specific medium of its production, transmission and consumption. The media through which literary text is communicated is as important as its form or content. This module explains the approaches to digital forms of media and addresses the shifts and new possibilities offered by the emerging technologies. It concludes with a case study to establish the linkage between media, culture and literature.
topics: Approaches to Digital forms of Media
Representation of Partition in Different Media: A Historical and Cultural Analysis I
Representation of Partition in Different Media: A Historical and Cultural Analysis II

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module provides an insight into the gamification and ludification of our culture, described in detail in the topic of game studies. The module also covers body culture studies which explains how the composition of our body affects the psyche of the people and representation of a body through different media. You will also be introduced to the concept of how gender conditioning is important when we use language.
topics: Developments in Cultural Studies: Learning Outcomes
Body Culture Studies and Representation of Women in Media
Media and Language, Glass Ceiling in Media
Developments in Cultural Studies : Lesson Summary
